Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Portable, Image-Guided, Robotic Device for Fully Automated Venipuncture
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to greatly improve the accuracy, speed, and safety of blood draws and IV insertions by introducing a portable, fully-automated venipuncture device. Venipuncture is the most frequently performed invasive clinical routine in the United States (U.S.), occurring over 1 billion times per year, yet the success rate of manual phlebotomy depends heavily on the patient?s physiology and the practitioner?s skill. Failure rates, which can exceed 50% in difficult populations, may lead to a wide range of complications including injury to the patient and an increased risk of blood borne transfection to the practitioner. Consequently, failed venipuncture is the most common cause of patient and practitioner complications in the U.S., and incurs nearly $5 billion in material, time, and labor costs to the U.S. healthcare system each year. The current research aims to address these challenges by developing the automated venipuncture device to ensure rapid, single-stick venous access across all patient demographics. The research furthermore enhances scientific and technological understanding by demonstrating a first step in the miniaturization and automation of precision robotic systems for routine clinical interventions.


The proposed project will substantially increase the accuracy and safety of the automated venipuncture device, while validating the device in animals as a step toward clinical translation. The technology combines three-dimensional (3D) near infrared and ultrasound imaging, real-time image analysis software, and a miniaturized seven degrees-of-freedom robot that steers the needle based on image feedback. The system operates by mapping in real-time the 3D spatial coordinates of subcutaneous veins in order to autonomously direct the needle into a selected vein. By automating the phlebotomy procedure, the device would offer tremendous value to the medical field by providing healthcare professionals the ability to draw blood and start IV lines across all patient demographics with unparalleled accuracy and efficiency. In this way, the device would drastically reduce the number of needle placement attempts compared to manual phlebotomy. The device would also improve clinical safety by removing the practitioner from contact with exposed sharps, thus eliminating the risk of bloodborne infections. Once commercialized, the device has the potential to impact areas including pediatric and geriatric use, diagnostic laboratory blood testing, and emergency care.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I SBIR project focused on the development of VascuLogic’s VenousPro device designed to perform blood draws and other intravenous procedures with unparalleled accuracy and autonomy. The VenousPro is fit for use in hospitals and labs to improve first-stick success in cases of difficult venous access, common in pediatric, geriatric, obese, and chronically-ill patients. The device combines near infrared and ultrasound imaging, computer vision, and a miniaturized robot that steers the needle. The device operates by mapping the 3D position of a selected vein and guiding the needle based on real-time feedback. The Phase I goal was to increase overall system performance and to demonstrate feasibility through phantom and animal studies. Previous limitations were overcome by incorporating ultrasound guidance software and an automated needle handling system. Tail vein cannulations were then performed in rats to assess device accuracy. The outcomes of this work will guide the translation of the VenousPro prototype into a clinically viable medical device.

This SBIR Phase I project focused on the continued development of VascuLogic’s VenousPro™ device, a medical device designed to perform accurate, rapid, and safe intravenous access in an autonomous manner. The VenousPro™ is designed for use in hospitals and diagnostic labs to improve the rate of first-stick success in cases of difficult venous access, common in pediatric, geriatric, obese, and chronically-ill patients. The device combines near infrared and ultrasound vein imaging, computer vision and image analysis software, and a miniaturized robot that steers the needle based on image and force feedback.The device operates by mapping the 3D position of a selected vein and guiding the cannula into the center based on real-time image feedback. VenousPro is compact, lightweight, and thus amenable to a range of settings including lab table-tops, hospital beds, and crash carts. The overall objective of the Phase I research was to increase the accuracy and speed of the system and to demonstrate feasibility through in vitro phantom studies and in vivo animal trials. The Technical Objectives focused on addressing limitations of previous prototypes by incorporating real-time image analysis software to enable US-guided needle insertion, and an automated needle handling system to improve completion times while eliminating practitioner contact with exposed sharps. An animal study was then conducted to evaluate the imaging and robotic functionality in tail vein cannulations of adult Sprague-Dawley rats, as summarized below:

Obj. 1: Develop ultrasound image analysis algorithms for real-time needle tracking to improve device insertion accuracy. 13 image analysis algorithms were implemented ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This Phase I SBIR project focused on the development of VascuLogicÆs VenousPro device designed to perform blood draws and other intravenous procedures with unparalleled accuracy and autonomy. The VenousPro is fit for use in hospitals and labs to improve first-stick success in cases of difficult venous access, common in pediatric, geriatric, obese, and chronically-ill patients. The device combines near infrared and ultrasound imaging, computer vision, and a miniaturized robot that steers the needle. The device operates by mapping the 3D position of a selected vein and guiding the needle based on real-time feedback. The Phase I goal was to increase overall system performance and to demonstrate feasibility through phantom and animal studies. Previous limitations were overcome by incorporating ultrasound guidance software and an automated needle handling system. Tail vein cannulations were then performed in rats to assess device accuracy. The outcomes of this work will guide the translation of the VenousPro prototype into a clinically viable medical device. This SBIR Phase I project focused on the continued development of VascuLogicÆs VenousPro™ device, a medical device designed to perform accurate, rapid, and safe intravenous access in an autonomous manner. The VenousPro™ is designed for use in hospitals and diagnostic labs to improve the rate of first-stick success in cases of difficult venous access, common in pediatric, geriatric, obese, and chronically-ill patients. The device combines near infrared and ultrasound vein imaging, computer vision and image analysis software, and a miniaturized robot that steers the needle based on image and force feedback.The device operates by mapping the 3D position of a selected vein and guiding the cannula into the center based on real-time image feedback. VenousPro is compact, lightweight, and thus amenable to a range of settings including lab table-tops, hospital beds, and crash carts. The overall objective of the Phase I research was to increase the accuracy and speed of the system and to demonstrate feasibility through in vitro phantom studies and in vivo animal trials. The Technical Objectives focused on addressing limitations of previous prototypes by incorporating real-time image analysis software to enable US-guided needle insertion, and an automated needle handling system to improve completion times while eliminating practitioner contact with exposed sharps. An animal study was then conducted to evaluate the imaging and robotic functionality in tail vein cannulations of adult Sprague-Dawley rats, as summarized below: Obj. 1: Develop ultrasound image analysis algorithms for real-time needle tracking to improve device insertion accuracy. 13 image analysis algorithms were implemented in LabVIEW and OpenCV to compare accuracy and computational efficiency. These benchmarking studies allowed us to identify an approach based on line detection, corner extraction, and feature tracking that minimizedangle errors (~1°) and position errors (<1 mm) while maintaining a real-time processing rate of >25 fps. Obj. 2: Develop an automated needle handling system to eliminate practitioner contact with exposed sharps.The automated needle handling system comprised a robust electromagnet-based needle attachment mechanism and a re-loader system. In 50 cannulation trials on phantoms, the robot demonstrated the ability to engage the needle, remove the cap, and cannulate the phantom vessels with 100% accuracy. The free-space positioning accuracy of the needle handling system was observed to be 0.21 mm over the workspace of the articulated serial arm, and the repeatability of the system was 0.05 mm. Obj. 3:Assessin vivoaccuracy and speed in a small animal study.Device imaging and robotic performance were assessed via tail vein studies in adult Sprague-Dawley rats (Fig. 4). In imaging trials on 11 rats, 58% of tail veins and arteries that were undetected by manual visualization were c...
